title: CannTrust lays off an additional 140 employees as special committee probe wraps up
text:
CannTrust Holdings Inc. is laying off 140 employees, or roughly 25 per cent of its remaining workforce, as it attempts to recoup losses from the fallout of the unlicensed growing scandal that resulted in the suspension of the company’s Health Canada licence to cultivate and sell and cannabis.

The company’s stock was down almost eight per cent Friday morning on news of the layoffs, before paring some of those losses.



In a statement issued Thursday evening, CannTrust said the layoffs — which will occur in phases between late October and the end of 2019 — are expected to save the company approximately $400,000 monthly.

The company had previously laid off roughly 180 employees in August, including the master grower who was in charge of cultivation at CannTrust’s Niagara facility, which was the subject of a Health Canada investigation for growing in unlicensed spaces.

“This was a difficult decision, but it is imperative that our workforce reflects the current requirements of our business,” said CannTrust chief executive Robert Marcovitch. “Reducing the Company’s current operating expenses supports our financial sustainability, and places us in the best position to fully resume production upon the reinstatement of our licenses.”

CannTrust also announced that it had concluded a special committee investigation into the unlicensed growing, and had submitted a “remediation plan” to Health Canada on Oct. 21 that specifies how the company plans to regain compliance. Details of the plan, according the the company, include a comprehensive internal training program and a strengthened governance and operations framework.

“We will also take steps to recover all cannabis from distributors and retailers that has not already been sold to end consumers or returned to CannTrust,” the company said. In mid-October, CannTrust destroyed all its remaining inventory that was grown in unlicensed spaces, that amounted to roughly $77-million worth of cannabis.

The company also noted that the special committee found no evidence that any of CannTrust’s remaining board members “were aware of or engaged in any non-compliance issues.”

“I am very appreciative of the Special Committee’s determined efforts to complete the investigative phase of its mandate. Leveraging the Special Committee’s findings, CannTrust has taken swift action to begin addressing the factors that led to its non-compliance, including several involuntary departures from the Company’s leadership team,” Marcovitch said.

In the immediate aftermath of the scandal, CannTrust fired its former CEO Peter Aceto, and demanded the resignation of co-founder and chairman Eric Paul — media reports alleged that both Aceto and Paul had been aware of the unlicensed growing.

Thursday’s statement also clarified that CannTrust will refile its restated 2018 and first quarter 2019 filings, as well as submit its second quarter and third quarter earnings within the next 60 days.

“In our view, the company has taken important first steps towards achieving compliance with Health Canada, opening the door for potential licence reinstatement in the future,” said Canaccord Genuity analyst Derek Dley in a note to clients. “Having said that, there is still significant uncertainty whether CannTrust will eventually achieve full compliance in the near term. As a result, we continue to remain on the sidelines,” he added.

Health Canada recently reinstated cannabis company Bonify Inc.’s licence, after it was suspended in February for selling 200 kilograms worth of illegal cannabis in legal retail stores across Saskatchewan.
